**Arthur Gamgee**

Arthur Gamgee (1841-1909) was a British physiologist and biochemist who made significant contributions to the fields of physiology and biochemistry. **Early Life and Education**

Gamgee was born in 1841 in Scotland. He studied medicine at the University of Edinburgh, where he earned his MD degree in 1864. After completing his studies, he worked as a lecturer in physiology at the University of Edinburgh and later at the University of Glasgow. **Career**

Gamgee's research focused on the physiology of respiration, metabolism, and nutrition. He was particularly interested in the role of oxygen in the body and the effects of high altitudes on human physiology. His work in this area led to significant advances in the understanding of respiratory physiology. **Awards and Honors**

In recognition of his outstanding contributions to physiology and biochemistry, Gamgee was awarded the prestigious Croonian Medal and Lecture in 1891.
